quizzes.question:
Fill in the blanks to multiply each item in the list by 2 using lambda syntax.
[!raw!]
nums = [11, 22, 33]
a = list(map({0} x: {1}, {2}))
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]map[/h1]

The built-in functions [b]map [/b]and [b]filter [/b]are very useful higher-order functions that operate on lists (or similar objects called [b]iterables[/b]). 
The function [b]map[/b] takes a function and an iterable as arguments, and returns a new iterable with the function applied to each argument. 
[b]Example:[/b] [code format="py" codeId="385"]def add_five(x):
  return x + 5

nums = [11, 22, 33, 44, 55]
result = list([b]map[/b](add_five, nums))
print(result)[/code]
[b]Result:[/b] [code format="raw" ]>>>
[16, 27, 38, 49, 60]
>>>[/code]
We could have achieved the same result more easily by using [b]lambda [/b]syntax.[code format="py" codeId="386"]nums = [11, 22, 33, 44, 55]

result = list(map([b]lambda x: x+5[/b], nums))
print(result)[/code]
[note]To convert the result into a list, we used [b]list [/b]explicitly.[/note]

quizzes.question:
Fill in the blanks to remove all items that are greater than 4 from the list.
[!raw!]
nums = [1, 2, 5, 8, 3, 0, 7]
res = list({0}(lambda x: x{1}5, {2}))
print(res)
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]filter[/h1]

The function [b]filter[/b] filters an iterable by removing items that don't match a predicate (a function that returns a Boolean). 
[b]Example:[/b] [code format="py" codeId="387"]nums = [11, 22, 33, 44, 55]
res = list([b]filter[/b](lambda x: x%2==0, nums))
print(res)[/code]
[b]Result:[/b] [code format="raw" ]>>>
[22, 44]
>>>[/code]
[note]Like [b]map[/b], the result has to be explicitly converted to a list if you want to print it.[/note]
